Expectation1: Deliver packages on time and to the correct address
Situation1: A medical supply delivery must reach a hospital department on schedule to ensure patient care
Expectation2: Organize and lead religious education classes for children and adults
Situation2: The regular weekly religious education class for the parish's children is scheduled.
Story: I glanced at the clock on my dashboard, my hands gripping the steering wheel tighter than usual. The hospital’s address blinked on my delivery app, a red warning flashing: “Urgent—medical supplies for ER.” I knew what that meant. If I didn’t get there on time, someone’s care could be delayed. But my phone buzzed again, this time with a reminder from the parish: “Children’s class starts in 30 minutes. Please arrive early to set up.” I pictured the kids’ eager faces, the parents trusting me to guide their children’s faith. I was supposed to be their steady presence, their teacher and priest. But right now, I was also the only one who could get these supplies to the hospital on time. My mind raced, torn between the weight of two promises. I could almost hear the laughter of the children in the church hall, and at the same time, the anxious voices of nurses waiting for my delivery. My heart pounded as I sat at the intersection, the hospital in one direction, the church in the other, both expecting me, both needing me now.
